comments.commentBody:
Very well said. I support some limited financial assistance for schools and working with other countries through the United Nations to continue to help Afghan women and girls.

This war in Afghanistan has been very long, very costly in human lives and in adding to the indebtedness of our own country. Ultimately, those in that country must learn to stand up for their own rights, that is one thing we cannot do for them.
Fourth time is the charm?  He'll finally get it right?  He knows how to do this?

Dave Scott, your comments on putting pressure on the poor to move to a different state (by offering fewer benefits) hark back to the Poor Laws of England, which required paupers to return to their own parish for assistance.  As you point out, this sets up competition between parochial interests, rather than a sense that we are all in the same boat.

So when I get old or sick, I can just move across the state line to get better care. That's going to fly like a lead balloon with state tax payers. That's why this has to be a United States plan. Or else granny gets dumped off the gurney at the state line.

It's rumored in Iowa, that many disadvantaged Missourians and Illinoisans (neighboring states) move to Iowa because we have a more generous system.  (I've not check the numbers to see if this is true, but I believe it to be)   I don't mind helping the poor (my only rule is you work at something, take a bath,  and keep your surroundings clean and tidy), but I also don't want to be overwhelmed because Missouri and Illinois won't care for their own.  What is in place or is anything in place to prevent states from shirking their duties?

Somehow the phrase "strengthen, secure, save, preserve, and protect" sounds more like the logos we see on police cars and the military. This is fitting, since the nucleus of the conservative platform is to pay for the smallest possible government. They believe the police and the military are the only forces we need collectively. Everything else can be done more efficiently through private enterprise.

An often overlooked point in the Ryan plan is that instead of the federal government administering the various health plans such as Medicare and Medicaid, a lump will be sent to the states. This is merely tax shifting. Each state will then be forced to carry the burden of the poor, the elderly, and the sick. The taxpayer will still carry the burden.

Richard, I'll be interested to see details of which you write, especially about the continuation of a traditional Medicare package for those under 55. If that option is offered instead of vouchers, I'm hard pressed to understand where savings would come from, as I suspect that most would choose traditional Medicare.

With respect to covered procedures and pricing: covered procedures would presumptively be decided by evidence-based outcomes such as the national database assembled by the team at Dartmouth. With respect to government pricing efforts: government negotiation of prices for drugs and procedures (as occurs in other nations) could yield significant cost controls.

I do agree with you that discussion and debate are important to produce good policy.

I was traveling through Iowa a few years ago and stopped at a mall for a bite. I've never seen bigger people anywhere in the fifity (I've been through most). Somehow, fried butter on a stick doesn't seem like much of a solution to help curb the obesity epidemic that we've been hearing so much about for years here in the grand 'ole US of  A.
I don't go to fast food places often, but when I do, I have a grilled chicken salad and a diet soda. It's there if you want it. Nobody is forced to buy a burger, fries, and shake.

Most deep fat frying oil is a toxic stew of carcinogenic chemicals created from the long exposure to high heat and poor quality of the oil, much of it 'recycled', resulting in even higher concentrations of toxins !

Enjoy your Fair 'food' ! Make sure your health insurance is up to date.

Well, I would remind my fellow Iowan that, despite all the wonderful things about much of Iowa and especially Iowa City (I did a PhD program there), it is true that both "Iowa" and "Ohio" are each comprised of three vowels and a very soft consonant. So, orthographically speaking, yeah, not a dime's worth of difference between them.

Yes, and a few times a year (not just once a year) these same Hispanics and indigenous peoples, not to mention the Chinese and other Asian people--oh, and I'm forgetting disciplined Germans and skinny French people--- tuck into some SERIOUSLY fat-laden, artery-clogging celebratory foods, e.g. whole roast pigs are popular among a lot of Asians and Latinos, and as for European pastry--!

The thing is, these are OCCASIONAL indulgences, not eat-on-the-run daily meals. The people who eat them do so happily, without guilt, knowing they won't be having these foods for a while. And I wish that most Iowans get to enjoy their festive foods for a day, in the same way. Salut!
A hamburger is hardly the equivalent of eating BUTTER FRIED ON A STICK.

It's almost laughable.  Who didn't see this coming from 2 billion miles away?!  This is exactly why regulation of the financial industry is needed.  All the business anti-regulation fools need to understand that regulation (regardless of industry) was driven by past abuses.   Business, in the pursuit of profit, will push things to excess 98% of the time. It's only after the fact that everyone wrings their hands at the left-over mess.  How many examples do people need before they wise up?

Cameron of GA,

The 9/11 terrorists didn't need advanced weaponry, just the belief by the passengers that they would be safe and end up in Cuba or Libya.

The flight 93 passengers learned of the 9/11 attack and took matters in their hands. They rolled.

Since 9/11, the sneaker bomber, the underwear bomber were stopped by vigilant passengers.

When we go through checkpoints at airports world-wide, it is to prevent another terrorist attack.

This is exactly right. Competition in medicine drives prices UP not Down. This has been shown in study after study over the years. For example, if a population has one MRI scanner, adding a second requires competing for MRI technicians (limited supply.) Technician salaries escalate. Multiply this by the many new (translate expensive) services and voila, costs go UP.

The Ryan plan will cause costs to go up (just like Medicare Part D did) when competition is added to the Medicare insurance mix.

My bet is that the health of seniors will subsequently go down.

As a practicing physician, I see the Ryan plan as a disaster in waiting.

Remember! WE the people have the power to vote the bums out. No amount of Citizens United millions can buy our votes unless we LET THEM.

The greatest reward for anyone who believes in the power of one vote is to show the Corporate tycoons like the Koch Brothers, big oil, energy barons, Wallstreet bankers, etc. that their millions in secret donations couldn't and didn't BUY OUR VOTES.

Dr No – to add to what you said, when hospital A buys an MRI machine, there are likely going to be more MRI tests prescribed, in order to pay for the machine. The hospitals are in competition for patients, so hospital B needs to buy an MRI machine. Seriously, how many machines are needed per X population? How many people really need to have an MRI? There's a medical/industrial complex looking to preserve their markets.

Medicare is as close as this country has come to a single payer plan which is the only way to cut down on the obscene amount of money spent for the administration and marketing of health plans.
It is a myth that competition will improve medical care. What competition has brought is inflated drug prices, urban medical markets that are glutted with excess and highly expensive equipment, a paucity of care outside the urban areas and within urban areas for the poor, and inflationary price rises in medical costs despite an economy that is in recession.
Nothing has and nothing will ever come from Republican ideas to privatize the medical system except less care for all except those who can afford to pay for it, an ever decreasing portion of the population.
In the meantime, Congress continues to produce the worst record on legislation since the pre-FDR presidency. They fiddle while Rome burns.

Or, if we really wanted to be cost effective and improve general health care outcomes, we'd have a national health insurance, single payer plan - i.e., Medicare for all. Every major industrialized country has one and gets better outcomes than our ad hoc system. But then, by conservatives' point of view those countries are all wrong. I'd be thrilled with a health care system that didn't work any better than Canada's or France's (or Japan's, or Switzerland's, or Brittain's). If only we could afford to pay less like they all do.

No, I think Ryan and Romney will be accurately painted as Medicare destroyers from now until election day Tuesday, and they will pay the price for it.
Brilliant Idea.
@MNW - Yet another Simon & Garfunkel song! "A grateful nation turns its eyes to you___ Woo woo woo!"
And let's start with Paul Ryan's mother who must be 65ish!

Before committing to a Medicare voucher program ten years down the road, how about a pilot program now to test it out now?

Immediately move anybody over age 65 who is related to a Congressman or Senator, or their top five staff members, out of traditional Medicare into a voucher program where they will purchase their health coverage in the private market. These individuals will be generally well to do, well connected people who should have no trouble negotiating a good insurance deal.

Then have them report back how private insurance works for the elderly, before committing people born after 1957 to that same fate.

The recent BBC world poll on how various countries were perceived showed that 50% of Americans had a positive view of Israel. Australia, New Zealand and Canada had far fewer people with positive views, 25% or less.
Look it up. This is a worldwide view not just a European view. It is the US who has an anomalous view even at only 50 % postive rating.
Harry the simple explanation is that Europe is afraid of Hizbollah terrorism and has made a tacit deal: you can operate here if you don't bomb here.

hussein haridy- Although i don't think we should accept hezbollah, I think that you made some good points. Thank you for making a calm and rational
posting.

Hans, I was looking for a simple way to explore the types of knots that might hold using a uniform rope having a frictionless surface and a realistic if simple material tensor description, something you could call "proper". So perhaps the question as I posed it is too broad.

You are correct, the holding principle would be based on obstruction of slippage with normal pressure. A rope made of frictionless beads strung together like pearls on a a necklace, or even a chain of links of the same material, would do the job nicely. But then these would be what you call a "tricky concoction," which was not my original intent.
Right on brother

It's pretty cleat that certain activities that would be considered unethical by the average citizen are not technically illegal - and so they will continue. When powerful people have to consult their attorneys to advise them on what's acceptable, isn't the battle already lost. CEO's and bankers don't want regulation but they don't want to be held accountable for actions that are technically not illegal. Government officials can't bite the hands that feed them.

Average citizens will have to stand united against such despicable behavior and media outlets need to shine a continuous light on these bad actors.

Corzine's "punishment" will be starting a hedge fund and making only a few $million a year - ridiculous!

There was a deep throat mole inside the Reagan administration. His name was/is David Stockman. He wrote The Triumph of Politics. He explained (in excellent prose) how supply side economics is another term for trickle down. Stockman also said that supply side economics led to enormous budget deficits. Have you read Stockman's book? Has anybody? Has Stockman's book made a difference?

Supply side economics is alive and well.
It's not animosity so much as avarice.

Where does this animosity come from? Simply put, the "Puppetmasters" are weak, insecure people who only feel secure when they can control everything . They see everyone else as everything they secretly hate about themselves and want to stamp out. Look at Ryan, for example--it's a good bet he would destroy the programs that helped him after his father's death because they are a reminder of how powerless he felt. He probably thinks he'll be doing all those lazy, useless, weak SS/Medicaid/Medicare recipients a favor by teaching them a harder lesson in survival than he was privileged to get.

I have a dream. My dream is that some day there will be a "DeepThroat" mole inside the Republican Party that will spill the beans why it is that the Puppetmasters behind the GOP despise the common American so much.  Where does the animosity originate?  Talk about your "Death panels" for Granma and Gramps. When there is no feasible safety net left all that there is left is to just die.  When Mitt and Co. take over,  the conditions that Dickens described for 19th century London will look quite comfortable for millions of Americans trying to survive.  There will not be enough poorhouses or prisons.

Thank you NYTimes,

There is inescapable humanity deep inside all of us...trouble is, some will not let themselves go there.

one can only hope that the civil lawsuits with a lower hurdle of proof can get a conviction. failing that, people will have to take to the streets and fight to regain their democracy, which sadly has slipped away when unlimited money was allowed to flow through the halls of our elected branches of government.

anybody who can still believe that robust regulation of the financial industry is unwarranted is either delusional, sociopathic or simply a paid mouthpiece for those that would be regulated.

It looks like in Europe the tail does not wag the dog as easily as in the congress of the U.S. of A. But then too, there are not as many right wing religious fanatics with their lunatic ideas about a second coming in the "Holy City" of Jerusalem.

I have to disagree. There is not a shred of proof, that the Hezbollah terror threat against the US and Israel would stop if Israel changed it's policies. The reality, as most people know, is that the Hezbollah terror threat would only stop with the complete destruction of Israel, and even then I am not sure it would stop.

Prof. Name one time the Palestinians EVER agreed to any comprehensive peace proposal. EVER. Not under UN auspices in 1947. Not under UN Resolution 242 after 5 Arab countries thought they'd finally destroy Israel in 1967 but lost. Again. Not after being offered 100% of Gaza, a redivision of Jerusalem, and 95% of the West Bank by Ehud Barak with Bill Clinton or by Ehud Olmert with George Bush.

Regarding India/Pakistan. Are you kidding? No similarity? A partition due to religious conflict that caused the death of at least 500,000 people, with Sikhs and Hindus by the millions fleeing for their lives to India. Far more death and destruction than the partition of Palestine. Where is all the endless harping over the plight of Hindu and Sikh refugees that we hear as over Palestinians? And of course not a peep regarding the 600,000 Jews who fled Arab lands in the wake of Israel's creation due to murder and property confiscation. Could it because unlike the Arab countries, Israel and India made an effort to resettle their refugees, as opposed to Arab states who keep them in camps as political pawns?

Finally, maybe if the Arabs and Iranian mullahs weren't constantly trying to destroy Israel as they have been since mid 20th Century, Israel wouldn't need to make "repeated military threats against Iran, Palestine, or Lebanon" Being a professor, I'm confident this amazing new concept will eventually sink in with you.

While the suspicions about the Lebanon based, and Iran backed Hezbollah aiming selectively at the US and Israeli targets seem not wholly unfounded. Also, while avenging the Israeli invasion on Lebanon in 1982 or subsequent threats they seem to be exploiting the relatively liberal human rights and freedom culture of Europe, and the nuanced divergence of foreign policy approach and geopolitical interests of  the US and EU respectively in the Middle East. Beyond that, the Hezbollah seem not only taking full advantage of Europe's liberal asylum laws in spreading their terror network and charity institutions, but also driving a wedge between the US and Europe by showing tactical softness to Europe, while reserving all their ire against the US and Israel, viewing the two as their common enemy number one. If, the EU seems refusing to perceive the Hezbollah posed terrorist threat as gravely as the US does, or dilly-dallying in taking action against them, or not banning the organisation as desired by the US, the reason seems the US and EU don't see the Hezbollah through the same prism. This Hezbollah terror threat against the US and Israel will continue until Israel is prepared to change its anti-Arab, anti-Iran policy course, and appears serious about seeking a peaceful and amicable solution to the Israel-Palestine dispute, as against it's repeated military threats against Iran, Palestine, or Lebanon.
